importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking a pivotal moment in the Mariners' postseason journey, when Eugenio Suárez's grand slam brought the team within one win of the World Series for the first time in over two decades.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 1995 ALDS victory over the Yankees is referenced as a turning point in Mariners history, believed to have saved baseball in Seattle, setting the stage for the team's long-standing pursuit of a World Series title.
The 2001 ALCS, specifically Game 4, is referenced as a historical benchmark for postseason excitement in Seattle, with fans recalling a moment of unprecedented energy.

keyTakeAways: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning to give the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays, marking the second grand slam in franchise postseason history.
The Mariners now lead the series 3-2 and are just one win away from their first World Series appearance in franchise history, making them the only active MLB team without a Fall Classic appearance.
The game was emotionally charged, with Suárez bringing his daughters and wife to the postgame press conference, emphasizing family and personal fulfillment.
Cal Raleigh's two key home runs — a go-ahead homer in the eighth and a game-tying one in the fourth — highlighted the team’s resilience and revitalized the stadium's energy.
The moment was historically significant, as it marked the first time since 2001 that the Mariners had a game-tying or go-ahead homer in the eighth or later of a playoff game.
Raleigh's homer tied him with Aaron Judge for the most home runs in a single season in the American League, a notable achievement in postseason context.
The Mariners had previously come within two wins of the World Series in 1995 and 2020, but lost both times, adding to their historic exclusion from the Fall Classic.

namedEntities.name: Eugenio Suárez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Suárez’s grand slam in the eighth inning was the pivotal play that propelled the Mariners to a 6-2 lead and put them one win away from their first World Series appearance in franchise history, making it a defining moment in the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are the subject of the article, with their historic proximity to the World Series being the central theme, and their 24-year absence from the Fall Classic making them a focal point of national interest.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are the opposing team in the playoff series, and their earlier wins in Seattle created tension, making the Mariners’ comeback and Suárez’s grand slam a turning point.

namedEntities.name: Dan Wilson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: As the team's manager, Dan Wilson provided commentary on the emotional and historic significance of the crowd reaction and Suárez’s performance, emphasizing the cultural impact of the moment.

namedEntities.name: Cal Raleigh
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh’s two key home runs — a go-ahead homer in the eighth and a game-tying one in the fourth — were pivotal in turning the tide of the game and are tied for the most home runs in a single AL season.

namedEntities.name: Bryce Miller
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Miller was removed in the fifth inning after being struck by a two-out double from George Springer, which allowed the Blue Jays to score and tied the game, highlighting the team’s pitching vulnerability.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer’s two-out double in the fifth inning drove in Addison Barger, tying the game and demonstrating the Mariners’ offensive resilience despite early struggles.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Clement’s single in the sixth inning drove in Alejando Kirk, maintaining the Mariners’ offensive momentum and contributing to the game’s progression.

namedEntities.name: Addison Barger
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Barger was driven in by George Springer’s double in the fifth inning, marking a key offensive play that tied the game.

namedEntities.name: Alejando Kirk
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kirk was driven in by Ernie Clement’s single, contributing to the Mariners’ scoring in the sixth inning.

namedEntities.name: Bret Boone
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boone’s game-tying homer in Game 4 of the 2001 ALCS is referenced as a historical benchmark for postseason excitement in Seattle, showing the long-standing emotional connection fans have with such moments.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Judge
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Judge is mentioned as the player tied with Cal Raleigh in home runs during a single season in the American League, adding context to Raleigh’s achievement.

namedEntities.name: 2001 American League Championship Series (ALCS)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 2001 ALCS is referenced as a key historical moment when Seattle fans experienced unprecedented excitement, establishing a benchmark for postseason energy that this game now surpasses.

namedEntities.name: 1995 American League Division Series (ALDS)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 1995 ALDS win over the Yankees is noted as a pivotal moment in Mariners history, believed to have saved baseball in Seattle, and set the foundation for their ongoing quest for a World Series title.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eugenio Suárez hit a historic grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, giving the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays and pushing them within one win of their first World Series appearance in franchise history. The Mariners, who have never made it to the Fall Classic despite multiple playoff runs, are now just one win away from achieving a long-sought milestone. Suárez’s performance, which occurred in front of his family, was emotional and symbolic, echoing past moments like the 1995 ALDS and the 2001 ALCS, which are remembered for their cultural significance in Seattle. Cal Raleigh's pivotal home runs — including one tied with Aaron Judge for most home runs in a single AL season — further underscored the team’s resilience. The Mariners now lead the series 3-2 and will play Game 6 in Toronto on Sunday night.
title: Eugenio Suárez grand slam powers Seattle Mariners to within one win of first World Series
